content.what_it_is: The ERR_TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS error, also known as a redirect loop, occurs when the website keeps redirecting the browser between different URLs in an infinite circle. For example, URL A redirects to URL B, which redirects back to URL A. The browser detects this loop and stops loading the page to prevent crashing. This is almost always a server-side configuration issue, though client-side caches can sometimes retain old redirect rules.
common_causes: An HTTP to HTTPS loop happens when the server forces HTTPS, but the application or a proxy like Cloudflare sends requests back to HTTP, causing an infinite loop.
A WordPress URL mismatch occurs when the Site Address and WordPress Address settings in the dashboard do not match the actual protocol or domain being accessed.
Using Flexible SSL mode on Cloudflare while the origin server forces HTTPS causes a loop because Cloudflare sends HTTP to the origin, which redirects back to HTTPS.
Conflicting rewrite rules in .htaccess or Nginx configuration files can redirect a page to itself or a parent directory repeatedly.
SEO or Redirection plugins in WordPress often fight over how a URL should be handled, creating circular logic.
how_to_fix_users: Before assuming the site is broken, try these steps to rule out local issues.
Clear cookies for the site, as old cookies might be storing a session that is stuck in a redirect loop.
Try loading the page in Incognito or Private mode to see if the issue is caused by your browser cache or extensions.
Disable VPNs, privacy extensions, or tools like HTTPS Everywhere to see if they are forcing a protocol that causes the conflict.
how_to_fix_owners: Check redirect chains using the command line to see exactly what is happening. Run curl -I -L your-site.com to inspect the headers.
If you use Cloudflare, log in and check your SSL/TLS settings. If it is set to Flexible, change it to Full or Full (Strict).
Check your wp-config.php file to ensure you aren't hardcoding WP_HOME or WP_SITEURL to HTTP if you have an SSL certificate.
Rename your .htaccess file to .htaccess_backup to disable it. If the site loads, the error is in your rewrite rules.
If you are using a load balancer or proxy, ensure it is passing the X-Forwarded-Proto header correctly and your application is configured to trust it.
content.when_not_your_fault: If you are a visitor, this is rarely your fault unless your browser is aggressively caching an old redirect. If clearing cookies doesn't fix it, the website administrator must resolve the server configuration.

content.what_it_is: The 404 Not Found error is the most recognizable HTTP status code. It indicates that the server was contacted successfully, but it could not locate the specific resource, page, or file requested by the client. Unlike a 500 error, which indicates a server failure, a 404 error indicates that the server is functioning correctly but the requested content is missing.
common_causes: Typographical errors where the user simply typed the URL incorrectly.
The page or file was removed from the server without a redirect being set up.
Broken links where an internal or external link points to a destination that no longer exists.
Changing the URL structure in CMS platforms like WordPress without updating existing links causes 404s.
Misconfigured .htaccess or Nginx rules preventing the server from routing the request to the correct handler.
how_to_fix_users: Check the URL for spelling mistakes, extra characters, or missing slashes.
Move up a directory by deleting the last part of the URL to see if the parent category exists.
Use the site's search function to find the content you are looking for.
Clear your browser cache, as occasionally a browser may cache a 404 response.
how_to_fix_owners: If you moved or deleted a page, always set up a 301 Permanent Redirect to the most relevant existing page.
Use tools like Google Search Console or a broken link checker to identify and fix dead links on your site.
If you get 404s on all posts but the homepage works, go to Settings > Permalinks in WordPress and simply click Save Changes to flush the rewrite rules.
Ensure your server is configured to route requests to your application's entry point if the file doesn't exist physically.
Create a helpful custom 404 page with a search bar and links to popular content to keep users on your site.
content.when_not_your_fault: If you clicked a link from an external website that points to a page that no longer exists, the error is on the linking site or the destination site, not you.

content.what_it_is: The 500 Internal Server Error is a generic catch-all response indicating that the server encountered an unexpected condition that prevented it from fulfilling the request. It is the server's way of saying something went wrong, but it cannot be more specific. This usually implies a problem with the website's code or configuration rather than the server hardware itself.
common_causes: Syntax errors such as a missing semicolon or curly brace in PHP code.
A typo in the .htaccess file can instantly break the entire site on Apache servers.
A script tried to use more memory than the server allows, exhausting the PHP memory limit.
Incompatible code between two plugins or a theme update causing conflicts.
The server requires specific permissions to execute scripts securely, usually 755 for folders and 644 for files.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page, as the issue might be a temporary glitch or resource spike.
Clear your browser cache in case a cached version of the error page persists.
Come back later if the site administrator is working on the site.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server error logs immediately. The logs will tell you exactly which file and line number caused the crash.
Enable debugging in WordPress by setting WP_DEBUG to true in wp-config.php to see the error message directly on the screen.
Rename your .htaccess file to .htaccess_backup. If the site loads, the error is in your rewrite rules.
Increase the PHP memory limit by editing your php.ini file or wp-config.php.
Deactivate all plugins by renaming the plugins folder via FTP to rule out a conflict.
content.when_not_your_fault: As a user, a 500 error is strictly a server-side issue. You cannot fix it from your end.

content.what_it_is: A 502 Bad Gateway error indicates that a server acting as a gateway or proxy received an invalid response from an upstream server. In modern web stacks, this typically means the reverse proxy, like Nginx or Cloudflare, tried to talk to the application backend but received an error, a disconnect, or garbage data.
common_causes: The backend process, such as php-fpm, is not running or has crashed.
The upstream server is too busy to respond, causing the gateway to give up.
A firewall is blocking the connection between the proxy and the origin.
The upstream server took too long to process a complex request, and the gateway closed the connection.
The proxy is trying to speak HTTPS to an upstream server that only speaks HTTP.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page, as the server might have been temporarily overloaded.
Check the site status using a tool like Down For Everyone Or Just Me to see if it is a global outage.
Clear your cache to ensure you aren't seeing a cached error page.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your application server is running by checking the service status.
Inspect both the Nginx error logs and the application logs for connection failures.
Increase timeouts if the error happens on long-running tasks.
Ensure port 80 or 443 is open to the proxy server in your firewall rules.
If using Cloudflare, ensure your SSL mode matches your origin configuration.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the site is experiencing a DDoS attack or the hosting provider is having infrastructure issues.

content.what_it_is: The DNS_PROBE_FINISHED_NXDOMAIN error stands for Non-Existent Domain. It means the Domain Name System lookup failed because the domain name requested does not exist in the global DNS records. Essentially, the browser asked the internet's phonebook for a number, and the phonebook said there is no listing for that name.
common_causes: The most common cause is simply typing the domain name wrong.
The domain registration has lapsed, and the registrar has removed the DNS records.
You recently bought the domain or changed nameservers, and the changes haven't spread to your local ISP yet.
Your computer is remembering a previous not found result even though the site is now live.
Security software or firewalls blocking the DNS lookup request.
how_to_fix_users: Verify the spelling of the domain name in the address bar.
Flush your DNS cache using the command prompt or terminal.
Switch your network adapter's DNS settings to use Google or Cloudflare DNS servers.
Power cycle your modem and router to clear local network caches.
Temporarily turn off VPNs or security software to rule them out.
how_to_fix_owners: Check WHOIS records to ensure your domain hasn't expired or been suspended.
Ensure your domain is pointing to the correct nameservers.
Log in to your DNS provider and ensure there is an A Record pointing to your server's IP address.
If you changed settings recently, wait up to 48 hours for DNS to propagate globally.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the domain owner has let the domain expire, or if your ISP's DNS servers are down.

content.what_it_is: This error indicates that the DNS probe failed because there is no internet connection available to perform the lookup.
common_causes: No internet connection.
Router or modem issues.
Network adapter driver problems.
Firewall blocking internet access.
how_to_fix_users: Check if other devices have internet.
Restart your router/modem.
Troubleshoot network adapter settings.
Flush DNS cache.
how_to_fix_owners: This is a client-side issue, not a server issue.
content.when_not_your_fault: If your ISP is experiencing an outage.

content.what_it_is: The 403 Forbidden error indicates that the server understands the request but refuses to authorize it. Unlike 401 Unauthorized, re-authenticating will not make a difference. The access is permanently forbidden and tied to application logic, such as insufficient rights to a resource.
common_causes: Incorrect file or folder permissions on the server.
Corrupt .htaccess file.
IP address blocking by a security plugin or firewall.
Missing index file in the directory.
how_to_fix_users: Clear your browser cache and cookies.
Check if the URL is correct.
Contact the website administrator if you believe you should have access.
how_to_fix_owners: Check file permissions (directories should be 755, files 644).
Inspect the .htaccess file for errors or restrictive rules.
Disable security plugins temporarily to check for conflicts.
Verify that an index.php or index.html file exists.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website owner has intentionally restricted access to specific regions or IP addresses.

content.what_it_is: The 503 Service Unavailable error means the server is currently unable to handle the request due to a temporary overload or scheduled maintenance. It implies that this is a temporary condition which will be alleviated after some delay.
common_causes: Server resource exhaustion (RAM/CPU).
Scheduled maintenance mode enabled.
Spike in traffic overwhelming the server.
A misbehaving script or plugin consuming too many resources.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page after a few minutes.
Try accessing the site later.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server resource usage and upgrade if necessary.
Identify and disable resource-heavy plugins.
Restart the web server or PHP service.
Enable a CDN to offload traffic.
content.when_not_your_fault: When the server is undergoing scheduled maintenance or experiencing a global outage.

content.what_it_is: The 504 Gateway Timeout error indicates that a server acting as a gateway or proxy did not receive a timely response from an upstream server it needed to access in order to complete the request.
common_causes: The upstream server is down or overloaded.
Network connectivity issues between servers.
PHP execution time limit exceeded.
Firewall blocking the connection.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Check if other websites are working.
Restart your modem/router.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase the max_execution_time in PHP configuration.
Check the status of the upstream server (e.g., database server).
Review firewall logs for dropped packets.
Optimize database queries to run faster.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the issue lies with the hosting provider's internal network or an external API service.

content.what_it_is: The 400 Bad Request error indicates that the server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).
common_causes: Malformed URL syntax.
Corrupted browser cookies or cache.
File upload size exceeds server limit.
Invalid characters in the URL.
how_to_fix_users: Check the URL for typos.
Clear browser cache and cookies.
Reduce the size of the file you are trying to upload.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server logs for specific error details.
Ensure your application handles input validation correctly.
Increase upload_max_filesize if users are uploading large files.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server has a bug in how it parses requests.

content.what_it_is: The 401 Unauthorized error indicates that the request has not been applied because it lacks valid authentication credentials for the target resource. It is similar to 403 Forbidden, but specifically for authentication issues.
common_causes: Invalid username or password.
Restricted access to a specific URL.
Security plugin blocking access.
Corrupted .htaccess password protection.
how_to_fix_users: Double-check your login credentials.
Reset your password if necessary.
Clear browser cache.
how_to_fix_owners: Verify password protection settings on directories.
Check security plugins for aggressive blocking rules.
Ensure the authentication mechanism is working correctly.
content.when_not_your_fault: If your account has been suspended or disabled by the administrator.

content.what_it_is: The 405 Method Not Allowed error indicates that the method received in the request-line is known by the origin server but not supported by the target resource. For example, using GET on a form that requires POST.
common_causes: Incorrect HTTP method used in the request.
Server configuration disallowing specific methods.
Plugin or theme conflict in CMS.
Misconfigured API endpoint.
how_to_fix_users: This is usually a server-side or application issue, not a user error.
how_to_fix_owners: Check the code to ensure the correct HTTP method is used.
Verify server configuration to allow necessary methods.
Disable plugins to identify conflicts.
Check API documentation for correct usage.
content.when_not_your_fault: If you are a user, this is almost always a developer or server configuration error.

content.what_it_is: The 429 Too Many Requests error indicates that the user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ('rate limiting').
common_causes: Brute force attacks.
Aggressive web scraping or bots.
Rate limiting configuration on the server or firewall.
A plugin or script making excessive API calls.
how_to_fix_users: Wait for a while before trying again.
Stop any automated scripts or bots.
how_to_fix_owners: Adjust rate limiting settings on the server or firewall.
Identify and block malicious IPs.
Optimize scripts to reduce the number of requests.
Implement caching to reduce server load.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server's rate limiting is configured too aggressively for normal usage.

content.what_it_is: This error appears in the browser when the website takes too long to respond. The browser gives up waiting for the server to send data.
common_causes: Server is down or overwhelmed.
Slow internet connection.
Firewall or antivirus blocking the connection.
Incorrect proxy settings.
how_to_fix_users: Check your internet connection.
Disable firewall or antivirus temporarily.
Clear browser cache.
Restart your router.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server status and load.
Optimize website performance.
Increase server timeout limits.
Verify DNS propagation.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website server is down or experiencing heavy traffic.

content.what_it_is: This error indicates that the connection was unexpectedly closed by the server or a network device while the page was loading.
common_causes: Network interruption.
Firewall or antivirus interference.
VPN or proxy issues.
TCP/IP stack corruption.
how_to_fix_users: Check your network cables or Wi-Fi.
Disable VPN or proxy.
Flush DNS cache.
Restart your computer.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server logs for crashes.
Verify firewall rules.
Ensure the server software is up to date.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server reset the connection due to a configuration error or crash.

content.what_it_is: This error occurs when the browser cannot establish a secure connection to the server due to an issue with the SSL/TLS protocol.
common_causes: Invalid or expired SSL certificate.
Date and time on the client device are incorrect.
Browser cache issues.
Server does not support the requested SSL/TLS version.
how_to_fix_users: Check your system date and time.
Clear SSL state in browser settings.
Disable QUIC protocol in Chrome (experimental).
how_to_fix_owners: Verify the SSL certificate is valid and not expired.
Ensure the server supports modern TLS versions (1.2 or 1.3).
Check for mixed content warnings.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website has a misconfigured SSL certificate.

content.what_it_is: This error means the browser does not trust the Certificate Authority (CA) that issued the website's SSL certificate. This often happens with self-signed certificates.
common_causes: Self-signed SSL certificate.
Expired SSL certificate.
The CA is not in the browser's trusted store.
Network monitoring software intercepting traffic.
how_to_fix_users: Proceed with caution (only if you trust the site).
Update your operating system and browser.
Disable antivirus SSL scanning.
how_to_fix_owners: Install a valid SSL certificate from a trusted CA.
Ensure the intermediate certificate chain is complete.
Renew the certificate if expired.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website is using a self-signed or invalid certificate.

content.what_it_is: This is a Cloudflare-specific error indicating that the origin web server refused the connection from Cloudflare.
common_causes: Origin server is down.
Firewall on the origin server blocking Cloudflare IPs.
Web server software (Apache/Nginx) is not running.
Port 80 or 443 is closed.
how_to_fix_users: Wait for the site owner to fix the issue.
View a cached version if available.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure the web server is running.
Whitelist Cloudflare IP ranges in your firewall.
Check server logs for errors.
Verify port 80/443 availability.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website's hosting provider is down.

content.what_it_is: This Cloudflare error happens when Cloudflare could not establish a TCP connection to the origin server within the time limit.
common_causes: Server overload.
Firewall blocking Cloudflare requests.
Incorrect IP address in Cloudflare DNS settings.
Network routing issues.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Try again later.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server load and resources.
Verify Cloudflare IPs are allowed.
Ensure the origin IP in Cloudflare DNS is correct.
Contact hosting provider.
content.when_not_your_fault: If there is a network issue between Cloudflare and the origin server.

content.what_it_is: This WordPress error indicates that the PHP code cannot connect to the MySQL database. This renders the site inaccessible.
common_causes: Incorrect database credentials in wp-config.php.
Corrupted database.
Database server is down.
Disk space full.
how_to_fix_users: Contact the site administrator.
how_to_fix_owners: Verify credentials in wp-config.php.
Repair the database using WordPress repair tool.
Check if the MySQL service is running.
Contact hosting support.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the database server provided by the host is down.

content.what_it_is: The White Screen of Death (WSOD) is a common WordPress error where a plain white screen is displayed instead of the website content, with no error message.
common_causes: PHP memory limit exhausted.
Plugin or theme conflict.
Syntax error in code.
Corrupted core files.
how_to_fix_users: There is nothing a user can do.
how_to_fix_owners: Enable WP_DEBUG in wp-config.php to see the error.
Increase PHP memory limit.
Deactivate all plugins and switch to a default theme.
Re-upload core WordPress files.
content.when_not_your_fault: If an automatic update failed and corrupted files.

content.what_it_is: The 408 Request Timeout error indicates that the server did not receive a complete request from the client within the server's allotted timeout period.
common_causes: Slow internet connection on the client side.
Large file upload taking too long.
Server timeout settings are too low.
Network congestion.
how_to_fix_users: Check your internet connection speed.
Retry the request.
Compress files before uploading.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase server timeout values (e.g., client_body_timeout in Nginx).
Optimize application performance.
Check for network bottlenecks.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server has an unreasonably short timeout configured.

content.what_it_is: The 505 HTTP Version Not Supported error indicates that the server does not support, or refuses to support, the major version of HTTP that was used in the request message.
common_causes: The server is outdated.
The client is using a very new or experimental HTTP version.
Misconfigured server software.
how_to_fix_users: Update your web browser.
Try a different browser.
how_to_fix_owners: Update web server software to the latest version.
Check server configuration for protocol support.
Ensure no proxy is downgrading the protocol incorrectly.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is running obsolete software.

content.what_it_is: This error is a clear indication from the browser that the device is not connected to the internet.
common_causes: Wi-Fi is turned off.
Ethernet cable is unplugged.
Router is turned off or rebooting.
ISP outage.
how_to_fix_users: Check Wi-Fi or cable connection.
Restart your router.
Contact your ISP.
how_to_fix_owners: This is a client-side connectivity issue.
content.when_not_your_fault: If there is a widespread internet outage in your area.

content.what_it_is: The 413 Payload Too Large error indicates that the request entity is larger than limits defined by the server. This typically happens during file uploads when the file size exceeds the maximum allowed configuration.
common_causes: The client_max_body_size directive is set too low in the Nginx configuration file.
The LimitRequestBody directive in Apache is restricting the size of the HTTP request body.
The upload_max_filesize or post_max_size settings in php.ini are smaller than the file being uploaded.
The web application itself has a coded limit on file sizes for security or storage reasons.
how_to_fix_users: Use a file compression tool to reduce the size of the document or image before uploading.
If uploading multiple files at once, try uploading them one by one to stay under the limit.
Review the website's help section to see if there is a stated maximum file size limit.
how_to_fix_owners: Open your nginx.conf file and add or edit client_max_body_size 100M; inside the http, server, or location block.
Edit your .htaccess or httpd.conf file and set LimitRequestBody 104857600 (value is in bytes).
Update your php.ini file to increase both upload_max_filesize and post_max_size to values larger than your expected uploads.
After making changes to configuration files, always restart Nginx, Apache, or PHP-FPM for the changes to take effect.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server administrator has set an unreasonably low limit for file uploads that prevents normal usage.

content.what_it_is: The 406 Not Acceptable error occurs when a server is able to locate the requested resource but cannot deliver it in any format that matches the criteria specified by the client. Modern browsers and API clients send Accept headers that describe which response formats, languages, or character encodings they are willing to process. This mechanism is known as content negotiation. When the server evaluates these headers and determines that none of its available representations satisfy the request, it stops processing and returns a 406 response. In practice, this error is often misleading. While it is defined as a client-side issue, it frequently appears due to restrictive server security rules or misconfigured content handling rather than an actual incompatibility in formats.
common_causes: Security modules on the server rejecting requests based on header inspection, even when the request itself is valid.
The client explicitly requesting a response format that the server does not support.
Language negotiation failing because the client prefers a language that is not available on the server.
Character encoding requirements sent by the client that the server is unable to satisfy.
Application-level filtering that blocks requests with uncommon or unexpected Accept headers.
how_to_fix_users: Disable VPNs or proxies that may be modifying request headers before they reach the server.
Clear browser data to ensure outdated or corrupted headers are not being reused.
Try accessing the resource from a different browser or device to rule out local configuration issues.
how_to_fix_owners: Review server security logs to identify rules that are rejecting requests with a 406 response.
Ensure the server is configured to serve all response formats required by the application.
Inspect incoming request headers to understand what the client is asking for and why negotiation fails.
Temporarily disable security or filtering layers to confirm whether they are the source of the rejection.
Implement a fallback response format so the server can return a valid response when negotiation fails.
content.when_not_your_fault: If a server-side security update or configuration change introduces overly strict filtering, valid client requests may be rejected even though they are correctly formed.

content.what_it_is: The 415 Unsupported Media Type error indicates that the server refuses to accept the request because the payload format is in an unsupported format. While similar to 406 Not Acceptable, the distinction is important: a 406 error means the server cannot produce the response the client wants, whereas a 415 error means the client sent data (like a file upload or API body) that the server does not know how to process. This is common in REST APIs when a client sends XML to an endpoint that only understands JSON.
common_causes: Sending a request with the wrong Content-Type header (e.g., sending application/xml when the server expects application/json).
Uploading an image format (like WebP or HEIC) that the backend image processor does not support.
Missing Content-Type header entirely, causing the server to guess incorrectly or reject the data.
API version mismatches where the newer client sends a format the older server version does not yet recognize.
how_to_fix_users: Check the file extension and format of any file you are trying to upload.
If using an API tool, verify that your Content-Type header matches the API documentation.
Convert files to standard formats like JPG, PNG, or PDF before uploading.
how_to_fix_owners: Inspect the Content-Type header of incoming requests in your access logs.
Ensure your application's body parser is configured to handle the formats you expect (e.g., enabling JSON parsing in Express or PHP).
Provide clear error messages indicating which media types are allowed.
Update your API documentation to explicitly state supported Content-Types.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the API documentation claims to support a format but the server is misconfigured to reject it.

content.what_it_is: The 410 Gone error is a permanent version of the 404 Not Found error. It indicates that the resource requested was once available but has been intentionally removed and will not be available again. This is a powerful signal for search engines like Google, telling them to immediately de-index the page and stop crawling it, rather than checking back later as they would with a 404.
common_causes: Intentional deletion of a product page for an item that is permanently out of stock.
Removal of an old API version that has been fully deprecated.
A website restructuring where old content was pruned without replacement.
Malware cleanup where compromised files were deleted by security software.
how_to_fix_users: Stop trying to access the URL; the content is gone forever.
Remove any bookmarks or links pointing to this page.
Search the site for a newer version of the content.
how_to_fix_owners: Use 410 status codes only when you are certain the content has no replacement.
Configure your web server to serve a custom 410 error page explaining why the content was removed.
Check your sitemap to ensure you aren't directing search engines to 410 pages.
If the removal was accidental, restore the file or change the status code back to 200.
content.when_not_your_fault: If you followed a valid link from an external site, the error is due to the destination site removing the content.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED error occurs when the browser attempts to connect to a specific IP address and port, but the server actively rejects the connection. Unlike a timeout where the request disappears into a void, a refusal is an immediate 'no' from the destination. This usually means no program is listening on that port, or a firewall rule is explicitly blocking your IP.
common_causes: The web server software (Apache/Nginx) is not running or has crashed.
You are trying to access a port (like 8080) that is not open on the server.
A local firewall or host file entry is blocking the connection.
The server is configured to listen on localhost (127.0.0.1) but you are trying to access it via a public IP.
how_to_fix_users: Check if the website is down for everyone using an online status checker.
Clear your browser cache and flush your DNS.
Check your proxy settings; a dead proxy server often causes this error.
Temporarily disable your firewall to see if it is blocking the site.
how_to_fix_owners: Verify that your web server service is active and running (e.g., `systemctl status nginx`).
Check which ports your server is listening on using `netstat` or `ss`.
Review firewall rules (UFW/iptables) to ensure ports 80 and 443 are ALLOWED, not REJECTED.
Ensure your server is bound to `0.0.0.0` (all interfaces) and not just `127.0.0.1`.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is offline or undergoing maintenance.

title: Web Server Returns an Unknown Error

content.what_it_is: Error 520 is a catch-all response from Cloudflare when the origin server returns something unexpected or something that Cloudflare cannot interpret. It essentially means 'something went wrong, but we are not sure what'.
common_causes: The origin server crashed while processing the request.
Empty or invalid response headers from the origin.
The origin server connection was reset.
A firewall on the origin server is blocking Cloudflare IPs.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Clear your browser cache.
Try again in a few minutes.
how_to_fix_owners: Check your origin server error logs for crashes.
Disable your .htaccess file temporarily to rule out bad rules.
Ensure your firewall is not blocking Cloudflare IPs.
Look for scripts that might be sending empty responses.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the issue is a temporary glitch on the origin server.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_NETWORK_CHANGED error occurs when your device's network connection changes while the browser is trying to load a page. This could be switching from Wi-Fi to mobile data, or an IP address renewal.
common_causes: Switching between Wi-Fi networks.
Connecting or disconnecting a VPN.
Unstable Wi-Fi signal causing frequent reconnections.
Network adapter driver issues.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page once your connection stabilizes.
Restart your router if your Wi-Fi is flaky.
Update your network drivers.
Flush your DNS cache.
how_to_fix_owners: This is a client-side issue. Ensure your site loads quickly to minimize the chance of this happening during a load.
content.when_not_your_fault: If your ISP is changing your IP address dynamically.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_CACHE_MISS error happens when the browser needs to submit data (like a form) to load a page, but that data is no longer available in the cache. It often appears when you try to go 'Back' to a page that was the result of a form submission.
common_causes: Navigating back to a page generated by a POST request.
Browser cache corruption.
Poorly configured caching headers on the website.
how_to_fix_users: Click the 'Reload' or 'Resubmit' button presented by the browser.
Avoid using the Back button after submitting sensitive forms.
Clear your browser cache.
how_to_fix_owners: Use the Post/Redirect/Get pattern to prevent form resubmission warnings.
Configure proper Cache-Control headers.
Ensure your forms are handling state correctly.
content.when_not_your_fault: This is standard browser behavior to prevent accidental double-charging or double-posting.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE error indicates that the server closed the connection without sending any data back to the browser. The request reached the server, but the server just hung up.
common_causes: Server crash or process termination.
Backend script (PHP/Python) failed silently.
Firewall or security software blocking the response.
Database connection failure causing the script to exit early.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Clear your browser cache.
Try accessing the site in Incognito mode.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server error logs for segmentation faults or crashes.
Verify that your PHP/backend processes are running correctly.
Ensure error reporting is enabled to catch silent failures.
Check disk space usage.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is experiencing a critical failure.

content.what_it_is: The 414 URI Too Long error indicates that the URL requested by the client is longer than the server is willing to interpret. This prevents buffer overflow attacks and other exploits.
common_causes: A redirect loop that keeps appending parameters to the URL.
A client trying to pass too much data via GET parameters instead of POST.
Malicious attempts to exploit the server.
Broken links with excessive query strings.
how_to_fix_users: Check the URL for an endless string of characters.
Clear your cookies and cache.
Contact the site owner if a link is broken.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase the `large_client_header_buffers` in Nginx or `LimitRequestLine` in Apache if you legitimately need long URLs.
Switch from GET to POST requests for sending large amounts of data.
Fix any redirect loops in your application.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website has a bug creating infinitely long URLs.

content.what_it_is: The 411 Length Required error indicates that the server refuses to accept the request without a defined Content-Length header. The server requires the client to specify the size of the request body upfront.
common_causes: A client sending a POST or PUT request without a Content-Length header.
Chunked transfer encoding being used when the server doesn't support it for that resource.
Proxy servers stripping headers.
how_to_fix_users: This is typically a technical issue with the software making the request, not a user error.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your API clients are sending the Content-Length header.
Check your server configuration to see if it requires length for specific methods.
Update your web server software.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the software you are using is poorly coded.

content.what_it_is: The 412 Precondition Failed error indicates that one or more conditions given in the request header fields evaluated to false when tested on the server. This is often used with 'If-Match' or 'If-None-Match' headers for caching or concurrency control.
common_causes: The client is trying to update a resource that has changed since it was last retrieved (optimistic locking failure).
Browser cache is out of sync with the server.
Incorrect ETag usage.
how_to_fix_users: Clear your browser cache.
Refresh the page to get the latest version of the resource.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your application handles ETags and conditional requests correctly.
Check your caching logic.
If using a CDN, ensure it is not serving stale headers.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server's implementation of conditional requests is buggy.

content.what_it_is: The 416 Range Not Satisfiable error indicates that the server cannot serve the requested byte range of the file. This usually happens when a client asks for a portion of a file that goes beyond the file's actual size.
common_causes: Resuming a paused download where the file has changed or shrunk on the server.
Download managers requesting invalid ranges.
Server file corruption.
how_to_fix_users: Restart the download from the beginning instead of resuming.
Disable download managers.
Clear your browser cache.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your server supports byte-range requests correctly.
Check if the file being requested is valid and has not been truncated.
Verify that your compression settings (gzip/brotli) are not interfering with range requests.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the file on the server changed while you were downloading it.

content.what_it_is: The 417 Expectation Failed error indicates that the server cannot meet the requirements of the Expect request-header field. This is rarely seen in typical web browsing but can occur in API interactions.
common_causes: The client sent an 'Expect: 100-continue' header, but the server does not support it.
Proxy servers interfering with the Expect header.
Server configuration explicitly disabling Expect header support.
how_to_fix_users: This is usually an application or API client issue.
how_to_fix_owners: Check if your server or proxy supports the Expect header.
Configure your client to not send the Expect header if the server doesn't support it.
Update your web server software.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server claims to support HTTP/1.1 but fails to handle the Expect header.

content.what_it_is: The 501 Not Implemented error indicates that the server does not recognize the request method or lacks the ability to fulfill the request. Unlike a 405 error (where the method is known but not allowed), a 501 means the server doesn't even know what the method is.
common_causes: The server is outdated and does not support a new HTTP method.
The client is sending a malformed or custom method.
Server misconfiguration.
how_to_fix_users: Update your browser or client software.
Check if you are using a valid URL.
how_to_fix_owners: Update your web server software.
Check your server configuration to ensure it supports standard HTTP methods.
Review any custom modules or extensions.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is severely outdated.

content.what_it_is: Error 523 occurs when Cloudflare cannot contact your origin web server. This is different from a timeout; it usually means the network path to the server is broken or the IP is incorrect.
common_causes: The DNS settings in Cloudflare point to the wrong IP address.
Network routing issues between Cloudflare and the origin.
The origin server is down or unreachable.
Firewall rules blocking Cloudflare.
how_to_fix_users: Wait for the site owner to fix the issue.
Try again later.
how_to_fix_owners: Double-check your DNS A records in Cloudflare.
Contact your hosting provider to check for network outages.
Ensure your firewall allows Cloudflare IPs.
Verify your server's public IP hasn't changed.
content.when_not_your_fault: If there is a major internet routing issue.

content.what_it_is: Error 524 indicates that Cloudflare made a successful TCP connection to the origin server, but the server did not reply with an HTTP response before the connection timed out (usually 100 seconds).
common_causes: A long-running PHP script or database query.
Server is overloaded and processing requests too slowly.
Application is waiting for a third-party API that is slow.
Large file upload taking too long.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Try again later when the server is less busy.
how_to_fix_owners: Optimize your PHP scripts and database queries.
Increase the timeout limit in Cloudflare (Enterprise only) or your server.
Use background processing for long tasks.
Check server load.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is simply too slow to respond.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_NAME_NOT_RESOLVED error means the domain name could not be resolved to an IP address. It is very similar to NXDOMAIN but is the specific error code used by Chrome.
common_causes: Typo in the domain name.
DNS server issues.
Domain has expired.
Local DNS cache corruption.
how_to_fix_users: Check the spelling of the URL.
Flush your DNS cache.
Change your DNS servers to Google (8.8.8.8) or Cloudflare (1.1.1.1).
Restart your router.
how_to_fix_owners: Check your domain registration status.
Verify your DNS records are correct.
Wait for propagation if you recently changed DNS.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the domain does not exist or DNS servers are down.

content.what_it_is: Error 525 indicates that the SSL handshake between Cloudflare and the origin web server failed. This means Cloudflare could not establish a secure connection to your server.
common_causes: The origin server does not have a valid SSL certificate.
Cipher suites mismatch between Cloudflare and the origin.
The origin server does not support SNI (Server Name Indication).
Port 443 is closed on the origin server.
how_to_fix_users: This is a server-side issue. You cannot fix it as a visitor.
Try accessing the site later.
how_to_fix_owners: Install a valid SSL certificate on your origin server.
Ensure your server supports TLS 1.2 or 1.3.
Check that port 443 is open and listening.
Verify that SNI is enabled on your web server.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the hosting provider's SSL configuration is broken.

content.what_it_is: Error 526 occurs when Cloudflare is set to 'Full (Strict)' SSL mode, but the origin server's SSL certificate is invalid, expired, or self-signed.
common_causes: The origin SSL certificate has expired.
Using a self-signed certificate with 'Full (Strict)' mode.
The certificate common name (CN) does not match the domain name.
Incomplete certificate chain on the origin.
how_to_fix_users: Notify the website owner.
There is no workaround for users as this is a strict security check.
how_to_fix_owners: Renew the SSL certificate on your origin server.
Change Cloudflare SSL mode to 'Full' (not Strict) if using a self-signed cert (less secure).
Ensure the certificate covers the correct domain and subdomains.
Install the intermediate CA bundle.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the certificate authority revoked the certificate unexpectedly.

content.what_it_is: The 422 Unprocessable Entity error indicates that the server understands the content type of the request entity and the syntax is correct, but it was unable to process the contained instructions. This is common in APIs when validation fails.
common_causes: Semantic errors in the request body (e.g., missing required fields).
Validation errors (e.g., password too short, invalid email format).
Business logic violations (e.g., trying to purchase an out-of-stock item).
how_to_fix_users: Check the form data or API payload for errors.
Ensure all required fields are filled out correctly.
Read the error message details if provided.
how_to_fix_owners: Return clear error messages specifying which fields failed validation.
Ensure your API documentation matches your validation logic.
Log validation failures to identify common user errors.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the application's validation logic is flawed or too strict.

content.what_it_is: The 409 Conflict error indicates that the request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the target resource. This is most common during PUT requests.
common_causes: Trying to create a user with an email that already exists.
Version control conflicts (e.g., editing a file that was just changed by someone else).
State transition violations (e.g., trying to ship an order that is already cancelled).
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page to get the latest state.
Check if you have already performed the action.
Resolve the conflict manually if prompted.
how_to_fix_owners: Provide clear instructions on how to resolve the conflict.
Implement optimistic locking with ETags.
Ensure your database constraints are correctly mapped to error responses.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server state is inconsistent due to a bug.

content.what_it_is: The 507 Insufficient Storage error indicates that the server is unable to store the representation needed to complete the request. It is a WebDAV status code but can be used generally.
common_causes: The server's disk is full.
The user has exceeded their storage quota.
The database transaction log is full.
how_to_fix_users: Delete unnecessary files if you have a quota.
Contact the system administrator.
how_to_fix_owners: Free up disk space on the server.
Increase user storage quotas.
Check database logs and clear old backups.
Add more storage hardware or upgrade your hosting plan.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server runs out of space due to other users or system logs.

content.what_it_is: The 508 Loop Detected error indicates that the server terminated an operation because it encountered an infinite loop while processing a request with 'Depth: infinity'. This is specific to WebDAV.
common_causes: Circular references in directory structures.
Misconfigured symbolic links.
Infinite recursion in server-side scripts.
how_to_fix_users: This is a server-side configuration issue.
how_to_fix_owners: Check for circular symbolic links in your file system.
Review WebDAV configuration.
Debug recursive functions in your code.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server file system is corrupted.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_BLOCKED_BY_CLIENT error occurs when a resource (like a script or image) is blocked by an extension or setting in the user's browser.
common_causes: Ad blockers (e.g., uBlock Origin, AdBlock Plus).
Privacy extensions (e.g., Ghostery, Privacy Badger).
Browser security settings blocking mixed content.
Content filtering software.
how_to_fix_users: Disable your ad blocker for the site.
Check your browser extensions.
Allow the specific resource in your security settings.
how_to_fix_owners: Avoid using file names that trigger ad blockers (e.g., 'ads.js', 'banner.jpg').
Serve all content over HTTPS to avoid mixed content blocking.
Ask users to whitelist your site if necessary.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the user has installed aggressive blocking software.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_UNSAFE_PORT error indicates that the browser refused to connect to the requested port because it is considered unsafe. Browsers block certain ports (like 22, 25, 110) to prevent attacks like NAT slipstreaming.
common_causes: Trying to access a web server on a restricted port (e.g., port 6000).
Misconfigured links pointing to non-HTTP services.
Developer testing on non-standard ports.
how_to_fix_users: You cannot bypass this in modern browsers easily.
Contact the site owner to use a standard port.
how_to_fix_owners: Configure your web server to listen on standard ports (80, 443, 8080, 8443).
Use a reverse proxy to map unsafe ports to standard ones.
Avoid using ports listed in the browser's restricted port list.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the link you clicked specifies a blocked port.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_TUNNEL_CONNECTION_FAILED error indicates that the browser could not establish a tunnel connection through a proxy server to the target host.
common_causes: Proxy server is down or misconfigured.
Proxy authentication failed.
Firewall blocking the proxy connection.
Corrupted browser proxy settings.
how_to_fix_users: Disable your proxy settings in the browser or OS.
Check your VPN connection.
Clear browser cache and cookies.
Restart your computer.
how_to_fix_owners: This is usually a client-side or corporate network issue.
Ensure your server is accessible from outside the proxy network.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the corporate proxy server is malfunctioning.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_QUIC_PROTOCOL_ERROR indicates a problem with the QUIC protocol (Quick UDP Internet Connections), which is a modern transport layer network protocol used by Google and others to speed up the web.
common_causes: Unstable internet connection causing UDP packet loss.
Firewall or router blocking UDP traffic on port 443.
Browser bug in the QUIC implementation.
Server misconfiguration of HTTP/3.
how_to_fix_users: Disable QUIC in Chrome flags (chrome://flags/#enable-quic).
Check your firewall settings to allow UDP.
Reload the page (it may fall back to TCP).
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your server's HTTP/3 configuration is correct.
Check if your firewall allows UDP on port 443.
Monitor logs for QUIC handshake failures.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the ISP throttles or blocks UDP traffic.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_CERT_DATE_INVALID error occurs when the browser detects that the website's SSL certificate has either expired or is not yet valid (start date is in the future). This is a critical security warning preventing access to the site.
common_causes: The website's SSL certificate has expired and was not renewed.
The user's computer clock is set to the wrong date or time.
The certificate was issued with a start date in the future.
OS or browser is not updating root certificates.
how_to_fix_users: Check your computer's date and time settings and enable automatic synchronization.
Update your operating system and browser to the latest version.
Clear your SSL state in browser settings.
how_to_fix_owners: Renew your SSL certificate immediately with your Certificate Authority.
Set up auto-renewal (e.g., using Certbot/Let's Encrypt).
Check the 'Not Before' and 'Not After' dates on your certificate.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website owner forgot to renew their certificate.

content.what_it_is: This error indicates a mismatch between the domain name in the address bar and the domain name listed on the SSL certificate. The browser blocks the connection because it cannot verify that the certificate belongs to the site you are visiting.
common_causes: Accessing a site via IP address instead of domain name.
The certificate does not include the 'www' subdomain (or vice versa).
A redirect is pointing to a domain not covered by the certificate.
Using a certificate issued for a different domain on the same server.
how_to_fix_users: Check if you typed the URL correctly.
Try accessing the site with or without 'www'.
Avoid using the IP address to access the site.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your certificate includes all variations of your domain (Subject Alternative Names).
Configure redirects to point to the correct, secured domain version.
Install the correct certificate for the specific virtual host.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the site is misconfigured to serve the wrong certificate.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_ADDRESS_UNREACHABLE error indicates that the browser cannot reach the destination IP address. Unlike a timeout, this often implies a routing issue where the request cannot even leave the local network or find a path to the server.
common_causes: Router issues or local network misconfiguration.
The destination server is down or does not exist.
Proxy server settings are incorrect.
ISP routing failure.
how_to_fix_users: Restart your router or modem.
Check your proxy settings.
Try connecting to a different network (e.g., mobile data).
Flush your DNS cache.
how_to_fix_owners: This is primarily a client-side or network infrastructure issue.
Ensure your server IP is publicly announced and reachable.
content.when_not_your_fault: If there is a physical network cut or ISP outage.

content.what_it_is: The 407 Proxy Authentication Required error is similar to 401 Unauthorized, but it indicates that the client must first authenticate itself with the proxy server. This is common in corporate networks.
common_causes: Incorrect proxy credentials configured in the browser or OS.
Proxy server password has expired.
Browser is not configured to use the corporate proxy.
VPN connection issues.
how_to_fix_users: Enter the correct username and password for the proxy.
Check your browser's proxy settings.
Contact your network administrator.
how_to_fix_owners: This is usually an internal network configuration issue, not a public website issue.
Ensure your proxy server is correctly validating credentials.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the proxy server authentication service is down.

content.what_it_is: The 431 Request Header Fields Too Large error indicates that the server is unwilling to process the request because its header fields are too large. The request may be resubmitted after reducing the size of the request header fields.
common_causes: Too many cookies or very large cookies being sent.
Extremely long Referer URLs.
Authentication tokens (like JWTs) that are too large.
Looping redirects accumulating headers.
how_to_fix_users: Clear your cookies for the site.
Try accessing the site in Incognito mode.
Update your browser.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase the header size limit in your web server configuration (e.g., `large_client_header_buffers` in Nginx).
Audit your application's cookie usage and reduce size.
Check for infinite redirect loops.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the website sets an excessive number of cookies.

content.what_it_is: The 509 Bandwidth Limit Exceeded error is a non-standard status code used by many shared hosting providers (like cPanel) to indicate that the site has exceeded its allocated data transfer limit for the billing period.
common_causes: High traffic volume exceeding the hosting plan's quota.
Large file downloads consuming bandwidth.
Hotlinking of images by other sites.
DDoS attacks consuming bandwidth.
how_to_fix_users: Wait until the next billing cycle starts.
Contact the site owner.
how_to_fix_owners: Upgrade your hosting plan to get more bandwidth.
Enable hotlink protection to stop others from stealing bandwidth.
Optimize images and use a CDN to offload traffic.
Check analytics to identify traffic spikes.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the site is popular and the owner hasn't upgraded their plan.

content.what_it_is: Error 1020 Access Denied is a Cloudflare error that appears when a firewall rule violates the request. The site owner has set up a security rule that blocks your request based on IP, location, or behavior.
common_causes: Your IP address is flagged as malicious.
You are accessing from a blocked country.
Browser signature looks like a bot.
VPN usage triggering security rules.
how_to_fix_users: Disable your VPN or proxy.
Clear browser cookies and cache.
Contact the site owner with the Ray ID shown on the error page.
how_to_fix_owners: Check your Cloudflare Firewall Events log to see which rule was triggered.
Adjust or disable overly aggressive WAF rules.
Whitelist legitimate IPs or user agents.
Review 'Browser Integrity Check' settings.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the site owner has configured overly strict firewall rules.

content.what_it_is: Error 1000 indicates that the DNS records for a Cloudflare-proxied domain are pointing to a Cloudflare IP address. This creates a loop where Cloudflare tries to connect to itself instead of the origin server.
common_causes: An A record in Cloudflare DNS points to a Cloudflare IP instead of the origin server IP.
Importing DNS records incorrectly.
Misconfiguration when moving between Cloudflare accounts.
how_to_fix_users: This is a configuration error that only the site owner can fix.
how_to_fix_owners: Update your A or AAAA records to point to your actual web server IP.
Remove any records that point to Cloudflare's own IP ranges.
Ensure you are not proxying a record that should be DNS-only (grey cloud).
content.when_not_your_fault: If the site administrator misconfigured their DNS.

content.what_it_is: This PHP fatal error occurs when a script takes longer to run than the `max_execution_time` limit defined in the PHP configuration. The server terminates the script to prevent it from freezing the system.
common_causes: Slow database queries.
Infinite loops in code.
Processing large files or images.
Waiting for a slow external API response.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Wait a few minutes and try again.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase `max_execution_time` in `php.ini` or `.htaccess`.
Optimize your code and database queries.
Run long tasks in the background (cron jobs).
Check for infinite loops in your logic.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is under heavy load or the application is poorly optimized.

content.what_it_is: A PHP Parse Error (or Syntax Error) means the PHP compiler encountered code it could not understand. This stops the script from running entirely, often resulting in a blank page or error message.
common_causes: Missing semicolon `;` at the end of a line.
Mismatched parentheses `()` or braces `{}`.
Missing dollar sign `$` for variables.
Unclosed quotes.
how_to_fix_users: This is a coding error. You cannot fix it.
how_to_fix_owners: Enable error reporting to see the specific file and line number.
Check the line mentioned in the error for syntax mistakes.
Use a code editor with syntax highlighting (IDE).
Restore the file from a backup if you recently edited it.
content.when_not_your_fault: If a plugin or theme update introduced a bug.

content.what_it_is: This error occurs when the server requires a client certificate for authentication (mutual TLS), but the certificate provided by the browser is invalid, expired, or revoked.
common_causes: The client certificate installed on your device has expired.
The certificate is corrupted.
You selected the wrong certificate when prompted.
The server does not trust the issuer of your client certificate.
how_to_fix_users: Obtain a new valid client certificate from the administrator.
Remove old/expired certificates from your OS certificate store.
Clear SSL state in browser and restart.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your server is configured to trust the CA issuing client certs.
Check if the CRL (Certificate Revocation List) is accessible.
Verify the client certificate chain.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server's trust store is misconfigured.

content.what_it_is: The 511 Network Authentication Required error indicates that the client needs to authenticate to gain network access. This is most commonly seen when connecting to public Wi-Fi hotspots (captive portals) that require a login or terms acceptance.
common_causes: You are connected to a Wi-Fi network but haven't logged in yet.
The captive portal page failed to load.
Session timeout on the network.
how_to_fix_users: Open a non-HTTPS site (like http://example.com) to trigger the login page.
Disconnect and reconnect to the Wi-Fi network.
Enter the correct login details for the network.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your captive portal redirects users correctly.
Check that your authentication server is running.
Allow access to essential services (DNS, DHCP) before authentication.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the Wi-Fi network's login system is broken.

content.what_it_is: The 423 Locked error indicates that the resource that is being accessed is locked. This is a WebDAV-specific response code, meaning the file or directory you are trying to edit is currently in use or explicitly locked by another user or process.
common_causes: Another user is currently editing the file.
A previous session did not close the file handle properly.
WebDAV client misconfiguration.
Server-side lock timeout has not expired yet.
how_to_fix_users: Wait for the other user to finish editing.
Contact the administrator to release the lock.
Check if you have the file open in another program.
how_to_fix_owners: Check active WebDAV locks on the server.
Restart the WebDAV service to clear stuck locks.
Adjust lock timeout settings in your server configuration.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server fails to release a lock after a session ends.

content.what_it_is: The 424 Failed Dependency error means that the request failed because it depended on another request and that request failed. It is typically used in WebDAV when a PROPPATCH method fails because a previous command in the chain failed.
common_causes: A prerequisite request in a batch operation failed.
Dependency on a resource that is locked (423) or missing (404).
Client-side scripting error chaining requests incorrectly.
how_to_fix_users: Retry the operation.
Check if the files you are working with still exist.
how_to_fix_owners: Inspect server logs to identify which initial request failed.
Ensure all resources in the dependency chain are available and accessible.
Check for permission issues on related resources.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server state is inconsistent.

content.what_it_is: The 428 Precondition Required error indicates that the origin server requires the request to be conditional. This is used to prevent the 'lost update' problem, where a client GETs a resource's state, modifies it, and PUTs it back to the server, when meanwhile a third party has modified the state on the server, leading to a conflict.
common_causes: Missing 'If-Match' or 'If-Unmodified-Since' headers in the request.
Server configuration requiring strict concurrency control.
API client ignoring conditional requirements.
how_to_fix_users: This is a technical error usually handled by the application, not the end user.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your API clients are sending the necessary conditional headers.
Update documentation to specify required headers.
Check if a proxy is stripping headers.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is misconfigured to require conditions for safe methods.

content.what_it_is: The 506 Variant Also Negotiates error indicates that the server has an internal configuration error: the chosen variant resource is configured to engage in transparent content negotiation itself, and is therefore not a proper end point in the negotiation process. In simpler terms, it's a circular reference in content negotiation.
common_causes: Misconfigured content negotiation in Apache (TypeMap).
Circular references in .htaccess rules.
Server configuration pointing two resources to each other.
how_to_fix_users: This is a server-side configuration error. Notify the site owner.
how_to_fix_owners: Check your .htaccess or server config for circular content negotiation rules.
Review 'AddHandler type-map' settings.
Ensure your variant lists do not point back to the negotiation resource.
content.when_not_your_fault: Always a server configuration issue.

content.what_it_is: The 510 Not Extended error indicates that the policy for accessing the resource has not been met in the request. The server should send back all the information necessary for the client to issue an extended request.
common_causes: The server requires an extension to the HTTP protocol that the client does not support.
Missing mandatory extension declaration in the request.
Experimental server configurations.
how_to_fix_users: Update your browser or client software.
Check if the server requires a specific plugin or extension.
how_to_fix_owners: Disable experimental HTTP extensions if they are causing issues.
Ensure your server is compatible with standard HTTP clients.
Provide fallback mechanisms for clients without extensions.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server requires an obscure or non-standard extension.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_SPDY_PROTOCOL_ERROR indicates a problem with the SPDY protocol, a deprecated predecessor to HTTP/2. Even though SPDY is largely obsolete, the error name persists in Chrome for HTTP/2 related issues.
common_causes: Outdated browser.
Corrupted socket pool in the browser.
Antivirus or firewall interfering with secure connections.
Server-side HTTP/2 misconfiguration.
how_to_fix_users: Update Google Chrome to the latest version.
Flush sockets in Chrome: go to chrome://net-internals/#sockets and click 'Flush socket pools'.
Disable antivirus HTTPS scanning temporarily.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your server's HTTP/2 implementation is up to date.
Check Nginx/Apache logs for protocol errors.
Verify SSL/TLS configuration.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the browser's implementation of the protocol is buggy.

content.what_it_is: This error occurs when the server sends a response with headers that exceed the size limit the browser is willing to accept. This is the client-side counterpart to HTTP 431.
common_causes: Server sending too many Set-Cookie headers.
Excessive metadata in custom headers.
Server misconfiguration sending large debug data in headers.
how_to_fix_users: Try accessing the site in Incognito mode (fewer cookies sent back).
Clear cache and cookies.
how_to_fix_owners: Audit your server's response headers.
Reduce the number and size of cookies set.
Remove unnecessary custom headers.
Check for header duplication bugs in your application.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is spamming headers.

content.what_it_is: This error happens when the browser and the server cannot agree on a common encryption protocol (SSL/TLS version) or cipher suite. It's like two people trying to talk but speaking different languages.
common_causes: Server is using very old SSL versions (SSLv3, TLS 1.0) that modern browsers have blocked.
Server is using a cipher suite that the browser considers insecure (e.g., RC4).
Browser is outdated and doesn't support modern TLS 1.2/1.3.
QUIC protocol interference.
how_to_fix_users: Update your browser.
Check if the site works in other browsers (e.g., Firefox vs Chrome).
Disable QUIC protocol in Chrome flags.
how_to_fix_owners: Disable support for SSLv3, TLS 1.0, and TLS 1.1 on your server.
Enable TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3.
Configure a modern, secure list of cipher suites.
Use tools like SSL Labs to test your configuration.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is using obsolete security standards.

content.what_it_is: Error 1015 indicates that the site owner has implemented rate limiting rules on their Cloudflare account, and your connection speed or request frequency has triggered a temporary block.
common_causes: Refreshing a page too quickly.
Running a script or bot to scrape the site.
A shared IP address (like a VPN) sending too many requests collectively.
DDoS attack mitigation.
how_to_fix_users: Stop refreshing the page.
Wait 15-60 minutes for the ban to expire.
Disable VPNs to get a fresh IP address.
how_to_fix_owners: Adjust the threshold of your Cloudflare Rate Limiting rules.
Whitelist legitimate bots or APIs.
Increase the time window for the request count.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the rate limit is set too low for normal human browsing.

content.what_it_is: Error 1016 Origin DNS Error occurs when Cloudflare attempts to connect to your origin server but cannot resolve its IP address via DNS. Essentially, Cloudflare has the address you told it to visit, but that address leads nowhere or doesn't exist in the global directory. This typically happens when a CNAME record points to an unresolvable target or when the origin server's DNS records are missing entirely.
common_causes: The CNAME record in Cloudflare points to a target domain that does not exist or has no A records.
The root domain (apex) is missing an A record pointing to the server IP.
A Cloudflare Tunnel (cloudflared) is configured but the tunnel is down, deleted, or misconfigured.
DNS propagation delays after changing hosting providers or nameservers.
The origin server's DNS provider is experiencing an outage.
A typo in the DNS target value (e.g., pointing to `lb.example.com` instead of `lb-prod.example.com`).
The target of a CNAME record is itself a CNAME that fails to resolve (chaining issues).
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page after a few minutes, as the issue might be a temporary DNS glitch.
Clear your browser cache and flush your local DNS to ensure you aren't seeing a stale error.
If the site recently moved, wait for DNS changes to propagate (up to 48 hours).
Contact the site owner if the error persists, as this is a server-side configuration issue.
how_to_fix_owners: Log in to the Cloudflare Dashboard and check your DNS records tab immediately.
Verify that your CNAME records point to a valid, existing domain that resolves to an IP.
If using a CNAME for the root domain, ensure CNAME Flattening is enabled or add a fallback A record.
Use `dig +short target-domain.com` or `nslookup target-domain.com` to verify the target resolves.
If using Cloudflare Tunnel, check the tunnel status in the Zero Trust dashboard or run `cloudflared tunnel list` on your server.
Ensure your origin server's IP address hasn't changed if you are using A records.
Check for typos in your DNS records; a single missing character can cause this error.
If you recently updated DNS, use a global propagation checker to see if the changes have spread.
Review your Cloudflare Load Balancer pools to ensure the origin monitors are healthy.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the DNS provider for the origin server is down or experiencing a global outage.

content.what_it_is: Error 1033 indicates that the Cloudflare Argo Tunnel (now Cloudflare Tunnel) has failed. The cloudflared daemon on the origin server is not running or cannot connect to Cloudflare's edge.
common_causes: The cloudflared process on the server has crashed or stopped.
Network firewall blocking the tunnel connection.
Misconfigured tunnel credentials.
Server rebooted and tunnel didn't auto-start.
how_to_fix_users: Notify the site owner.
Try again later.
how_to_fix_owners: Restart the cloudflared service on your server.
Check the cloudflared logs for connection errors.
Ensure your server has outbound internet access.
content.when_not_your_fault: If Cloudflare's tunnel infrastructure is experiencing an outage.

content.what_it_is: Error 527 indicates an interrupted connection between Cloudflare and the origin's Railgun server (rg-listener). Railgun is a WAN optimization technology.
common_causes: Firewall interference between the Railgun listener and the origin web server.
Railgun listener is not running or misconfigured.
Network timeout between Cloudflare and the Railgun listener.
how_to_fix_users: This is a server infrastructure issue.
how_to_fix_owners: Check that the Railgun listener is active.
Ensure port 2408 is open and allowed.
Review Railgun logs for timeout or connection errors.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the Railgun service crashes.

content.what_it_is: This MySQL error occurs when the number of clients trying to connect to the database server exceeds the configured `max_connections` limit. It's like a store reaching its maximum capacity and locking the doors.
common_causes: Traffic spike on the website.
Persistent connections not being closed by the application.
Inefficient code opening too many connections.
Low default limit in MySQL configuration.
how_to_fix_users: Wait a few minutes and refresh.
The site is likely popular or under attack.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase `max_connections` in `my.cnf` or `my.ini`.
Optimize your application to close connections when done.
Use connection pooling.
Restart the MySQL service to clear stuck connections.
content.when_not_your_fault: If you are on shared hosting and other users are hogging resources.

content.what_it_is: MySQL Error 1045 indicates that the database server rejected the connection attempt because the username or password was incorrect, or the user does not have permission to connect from that specific host.
common_causes: Wrong username or password in `wp-config.php` or application config.
User does not have privileges for the specific database.
Trying to connect from a remote IP that is not whitelisted.
how_to_fix_users: Contact the site administrator.
how_to_fix_owners: Verify database credentials in your configuration files.
Reset the database user password.
Grant proper privileges using `GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES` command.
Check if the user is allowed to connect from `localhost` or `%` (remote).
content.when_not_your_fault: If the database server permissions were corrupted.

content.what_it_is: This PHP fatal error occurs when a script tries to allocate more memory than the `memory_limit` directive allows. It is one of the most common causes of the White Screen of Death.
common_causes: Loading large images or datasets into memory.
Inefficient code or infinite loops creating objects.
Using a plugin that requires more resources than allocated.
Low default memory limit (e.g., 32M).
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase `memory_limit` in `php.ini`, `.htaccess`, or `wp-config.php` (e.g., to 256M).
Optimize code to use less memory (e.g., process data in chunks).
Disable resource-heavy plugins.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the hosting provider enforces a strict low memory limit.

content.what_it_is: The 451 Unavailable For Legal Reasons error indicates that the server is denying access to the resource as a consequence of a legal demand. This is often used for censorship or GDPR compliance where content is blocked in specific regions.
common_causes: Government censorship or court orders blocking specific content.
GDPR or copyright (DMCA) restrictions preventing access from certain countries.
ISP-level blocking of illegal content.
how_to_fix_users: Use a VPN to access the content from a different region (if legal).
Contact the site owner to see if the block is intentional.
Check if the content is available on other platforms.
how_to_fix_owners: Ensure your geo-blocking rules are correctly targeted.
Provide a clear explanation on the error page citing the legal reason.
Review legal takedown requests to ensure validity before blocking.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the content is blocked due to laws in your country.

content.what_it_is: The 421 Misdirected Request error happens when a request is directed at a server that is not able to produce a response. This often occurs with HTTP/2 connection reuse where a single connection is used for multiple domains that resolve to the same IP but have different SSL certificates.
common_causes: HTTP/2 connection coalescing issues.
SSL certificate mismatches on shared hosting.
Misconfigured load balancers routing traffic to the wrong backend.
how_to_fix_users: Clear your browser cache and cookies.
Try accessing the site in Incognito mode.
Use a different browser to force a new connection.
how_to_fix_owners: Disable HTTP/2 connection reuse if certificates do not match.
Ensure your SSL certificates cover all domains served by the IP.
Check load balancer configuration for correct host header routing.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server's HTTP/2 implementation is aggressive with connection reuse.

content.what_it_is: The 426 Upgrade Required error indicates that the server refuses to perform the request using the current protocol but might be willing to do so after the client upgrades to a different protocol. This is common with WebSocket connections.
common_causes: Client trying to use HTTP/1.1 when HTTP/2 is required.
WebSocket handshake failure.
API requiring TLS 1.2+ when client uses older version.
how_to_fix_users: Update your browser or client software.
Ensure your network supports WebSockets.
how_to_fix_owners: Check your server's protocol upgrade settings.
Ensure WebSocket headers (Upgrade, Connection) are passed correctly by proxies.
Provide clear instructions on required protocols in API documentation.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server requires a protocol your device does not support.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_CONNECTION_CLOSED error indicates that the server unexpectedly closed the connection. Unlike a reset, this is a clean closure, meaning the server said 'goodbye' before sending data.
common_causes: Server overloaded and dropping connections.
Misconfigured server-side keep-alive settings.
Network proxy closing idle connections too fast.
VPN or firewall interference.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Check your VPN or proxy settings.
Flush your DNS cache.
how_to_fix_owners: Check server logs for premature closures.
Adjust `keepalive_timeout` settings in Nginx/Apache.
Ensure your server has enough worker processes.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the server is under heavy load.

content.what_it_is: The ERR_BLOCKED_BY_RESPONSE error occurs when the browser blocks a request because the server's response headers (like X-Frame-Options) forbid it. This often happens when trying to embed a site in an iframe.
common_causes: Embedding a site that has `X-Frame-Options: DENY` or `SAMEORIGIN`.
Cross-Origin Read Blocking (CORB) security checks.
Content Security Policy (CSP) violations.
how_to_fix_users: Open the link in a new tab instead of viewing it embedded.
Disable extensions that might be modifying headers (not recommended).
how_to_fix_owners: Adjust `X-Frame-Options` header if you want to allow embedding.
Configure Content Security Policy (CSP) to whitelist specific domains.
Check CORS headers for API requests.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the site owner intentionally blocks embedding.

content.what_it_is: MySQL Error 2006 'MySQL server has gone away' means the connection to the database was lost during a query. This is different from a connection failure; the connection existed but died.
common_causes: The query was too large (exceeding `max_allowed_packet`).
The server timed out the connection (exceeding `wait_timeout`).
The MySQL server crashed or was restarted.
Network glitch between PHP and MySQL server.
how_to_fix_users: Refresh the page.
Wait a few minutes if the server is restarting.
how_to_fix_owners: Increase `max_allowed_packet` in `my.cnf`.
Increase `wait_timeout` for long-running scripts.
Check MySQL error logs for crashes.
Optimize large queries to send less data.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the database server crashed due to a bug.

content.what_it_is: MySQL Error 2002 indicates that PHP cannot connect to the MySQL server socket or TCP port. It usually means the database server is not running or the socket file is missing.
common_causes: MySQL service is stopped.
Wrong socket path in `php.ini` or `wp-config.php`.
Firewall blocking port 3306.
Trying to connect to `localhost` when the socket is disabled.
how_to_fix_users: Contact the site administrator.
how_to_fix_owners: Start the MySQL service (`systemctl start mysql`).
Check if `mysql.sock` exists and matches your config.
Try changing `localhost` to `127.0.0.1` to force TCP instead of socket.
Check firewall rules for port 3306.
content.when_not_your_fault: If the hosting provider's database server is down.

content.what_it_is: Error 1101 indicates that a Cloudflare Worker (serverless script) threw a JavaScript exception during runtime. This means the code running on the edge crashed.
common_causes: Bug in the Worker script code.
Unhandled promise rejection.
Exceeding CPU or memory limits for the Worker.
API failure called by the Worker.
how_to_fix_users: Notify the site owner.
There is no workaround for users.
